sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: This very individual Pattern, in a blue Pink, had been infinitely charming.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Don't you think it pretty, Deidamia?

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, Lady Pyrrha.—Nay, dear Child, how can any Creature have so little Curiosity!

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p:
Look upon it again, Madam.—Never was so de
lightful a Mixture!

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: So soft! so mellow!

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p: So advantageous for the Complexion!

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: I can't bear it, Man; the Colour is frightful.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I hate our own tame home-bred Fancy.—I own I like the Design—but take it away, Man.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: There must be something pretty in every thing that is foreign.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: I am sure, Madam, this must convince you to the contrary.—Never was any thing so detestable!

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: For Heavens sake, Sir, open that other Packet; and take away this hideous Trumpery.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p: How coud'st thou make this Mistake?—Never was such an eternal Blunderer.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How ridiculous is this Accident!

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: Pardon the Mistake, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: A Suit of Armour!—You see, Philoe, they can at least equip us for the Camp.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Nay, Lesbia, for that Matter it might serve many a
stiff awkward Creature that we see every Day in the Drawing
room;
sor their Dress is every way as absurd and preposterous.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p:
If your Expectations, Ladies, are not now answer'd, let Fancy own herself at a stand. 'Tis inimitable! 'Tis irre
sistible!

div.stage:
[As the Ladies are employ'd in examining the Stuffs, Achil
les is handling and poising the Armour, Ulysses observing him.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p:
The Workmanship is curious; and so justly mount
ed! This very Sword seems fitted to my Hand.—The Shield too is so little cumbersome; so very easy!—Was Hector here, the Fate of Troy shou'd this Instant be decided.—How my Heart burns to meet him!

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p: [Aside to Diom. That intrepid Air! That Godlike Look! It must be He! His Nature, his Disposition shews him▪ through the Disguise [To Achilles.] Son of Thetis, I know thee, Greece demands thee, and now, Achilles, the House of Priam shakes.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: But what are you, Friend, who thus presume to know me?

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p: You cannot be a Stranger, Sir, to the Name of Ulysses.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: As I have long honour'd, I shall now endeavour, Sir, to emulate your Fame.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p: Know, Sir, Diomedes; He too is ambitious to attend you, and partake your Glory.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: Come Agyrtes; with him we carry Conquest to the Confederates.

div.stage: [Agyrtes takes a Trumpet which lay amongst the Armour, and sounds.

body.head: AIR XLVII. My Dame hath a lame tame Crane.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.l: Thy Fate then, O Troy, is decreed.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: How I pant!

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: How I burn for the Fight.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Hark, Glory calls.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Now great Hector shall bleed.

sp.speaker: Agyr.
sp.l: Fame shall our Deeds requite.

div.stage: [As Achilles is going off, he turns and looks on Deidamia.

body.head: AIR XLVIII. Geminiani's Minuet.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Beauty weeps.—Ah, why that Languish?
See she calls and bids me stay.
How can I leave her? my Heart feels her Anguish.
Hence, Fame and Glory. Love wins the Day.

div.stage: Trumpet sounds, and he takes 'em up again.

body.head: AIR My Dame hath a lame, &c.
body.p: as before, Sung in Four Parts as a Catch.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p: Thy Fate then, O Troy, is decreed.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: How I pant! How I burn for the Fight!

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: Hark, Glory calls. Now great Hector shall bleed.

sp.speaker: Agyr.
sp.p: Fame shall our Deeds requite.

div.stage: [As they are going; Achilles stops with his Eyes fix'd on Deidamia.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, Ladies, support Deidamia.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Never was any thing so astonishing!

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Run then, Artemona, and acquaint the King and Queen with what hath happen'd.

div.head: SCENE XI.
div.stage: Philoe, Lesbia, Deidamia, Achilles, Diomedes, Ulysses, Agyrtes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ah Sister, Sister, the Mystery then of that particular Intimacy between you and Pyrrha is at last unravell'd.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p:
Now if it had not been a Man of this prodigious Con
sequence, it had been the same thing.—Sure never unguarded Woman was so unaccountably lucky!

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Can you leave me, Achilles?—Can you?

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p: Consider your own Glory, Sir.

body.head: AIR XLIX. Gavotte of Corelli.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Why this Pain?
Love adieu,
Break thy Chain,
Fame pursue.
Ah, false Heart,
Can'st thou part?
Oaths and Vows have bound me.
Fame cries, Go;
Love says, No.
Why d'ye thus confound me?

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Think of my Condition.—Save my Honour.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p: Think of the Honour of Greece.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Think of your solemn Oaths and Promises.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p: Nations depend upon you.—Victory, Sir, calls you hence.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Can you, Achilles, be perfidious?

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p: Can you lose your Glory in the Arms of a Woman?

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Can you sacrifice the Fame of your faithful Deidamia?

body.head: AIR L. The Scheme.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: O, what a Conflict's in my Breast!

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.l: What, still in suspence? bid Fame adieu.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: See me with Shame opprest:
I curse, yet I love thee too.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.l: Let not her Sighs unman your Heart.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: Can you then go, and Faith resign?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Shou'd I!—How can I part?

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: Your Honour is link'd with mine.

div.head: SCENE The Last.
div.stage:
Philoe, Lesbia, Deidamia, Achilles, Ulysses, Arte
mona, Diomedes, Agyrtes, Lycomedes, Theaspe, Diphilus, Periphas, Ajax.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p:
Hence, Diphilus; and presume no more to come into my Presence. 'Twas your paltry Flattery that made me ridi
culous.—Such a Genius can never be at a loss for Employ
ment, for I have found you qualified for the very meanest Offices.

sp.speaker: Theas.
sp.p: My Daughter, Sir, I hope, hath put Confidence in a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: My Word, Madam, is as sacred as the most religious Ceremony.—Yet (though we are already solemnly betroth'd to each other) 'tis my Request, Madam, that before I leave the Court the Priest may confirm the Marriage.

sp.speaker: Theas.
Lycom.
sp.p:
You must own, Madam, that 'twas your own Jeal
ousies that were the Occasion of Deidamia's Disgrace.

sp.speaker: Theas.
sp.p: How can you have the Assurance to name it? Does it not put you in mind of your own?—Let her Marriage to Achilles make us forget every thing past.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: As you was so furiously in Love, Lord Ajax, I hope I shall still retain your Friendship.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: No joking I beg you, young Man.—But pr'ythee, how came you here? and in a Woman's Dress too!—Your setting out, Stripling, did not seem to promise much.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: The Adventure wou'd be too long to tell you.—I shall reserve the Story for the Camp.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: The Priest, Sir, is ready.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: The Ceremony waits you.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: It shall be my Study, Lycomedes, to deserve this Alliance.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: May you be happy!

sp.speaker: Theas.
sp.p: Let the Priest then join your Hands.

div.stage: [Achilles, Deidamia, Lycomedes, Theaspe, Lesbia, Philoe, Artemona, retire to the back part of the Stage. The Priest performs the Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Our Duel, Ajax, had made a much better Figure if there had been a Woman in the Case.—But you know, like Men of violent Honour, we were so very valiant that we did not know what we were fighting for.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: If you are too free with your Wit, Periphas, perhaps we may know what we quarrel about.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p:
What testy, Ajax! Petticoats have led many a Man in
to an Error. How lucky was the Discovery! for had you found a real complying Woman you had irretrievably been married.—The Presence of Achilles shall now animate the War.

body.head: AIR LI. The Man that is drunk, &c.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Was ever a Lover so happily freed!

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Try me no more; and mention it never.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.l: Suppose you had found her a Woman indeed.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Must I be teaz'd and worried for ever!

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: By Conquest in Battle we finish the Strife;

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: But Marriage had kept you in Quarrels for Life.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Must you be fleering?
Truce with your jeering.
Know that you Wits oft' paid for your sneering.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: If you had been deceiv'd by a Woman—'tis what we are all liable to.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: But Ajax is a Man of warm Imagination.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: After this Day let me hear no more of this ridiculous Affair.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nay for that matter any Man might have been deceiv'd; for Love, you know, is blind.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: With my Sword I can answer any Man.—I tell you, I hate joking.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: I have the common Cause so much at Heart that I wou'd not, Son, detain you from the Siege.

body.head: AIR LII. There liv'd long ago in a Country Place.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: How short was my Calm! in a Moment 'tis past;
Fresh Sorrows arise, and my Day is o'ercast.
But since 'tis decreed.—Let me stifle this Tear.
Be bold, yet be cautious; my Life is thy Care;
On thine it depends; 'tis for thee that I fear.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
Ajax.
sp.p:
But hearkee, young Fellow,—This is the old Soldier's Play; for we seldom leave Quarters but the Landlord's Daugh
ter is the better for us.—Hah!

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.p: We may for a while put on a feign'd Character, but Nature is so often unguarded that it will shew itself.—'Tis to the Armour we owe Achilles.

body.head: AIR LIII. Minuet of Corelli.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.l: Nature breaks forth at the Moment unguarded;

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Through all Disguise she her self must betray.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.l: Heav'n with Success hath our Labours rewarded.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Let's with Achilles over Genius obey.

body.head: AIR LIV. Saraband of Corelli.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.l: Thus when the Cat had once all Woman's Graces;
Courtship, Marriage won her Embraces:
Forth lept a Mouse; she, forgetting Enjoyment,
Quits her fond Spouse for her former Employment.

body.head: CHORUS.
Minuet of Corelli.
body.l: Nature breaks forth at the Moment unguarded;
Through all Disguise she herself must betray.
Heav'n with Success hath our Labours rewarded;
Let's with Achilles our Genius obey.

div.p:
February 28, 1733. Just Publish'd, A SELECT COLLECTION of MOLIERE's Co
MEDIES, French and English, in EIGHT POCKET VOLUMES, neatly Printed on a Fine Paper, with a curious Frontispiece to each Comedy. To which is prefix'd a curious PRINT of the AUTHOR, and his LIFE in French and English; Extracted from Monsieur Bayle, Rapin, &c.

N. B. That it may be seen how much the English Stage has been indebted to Moliere, we have, in this Catalogue, plac'd such of Our Comedies as have been founded upon His over-against the Originals, from whence they were taken.

div.p:
⁂ Just Publish'd, The TRAVELS and ADVENTURES of the Sieur JACQUES MASSE: Being a very entertaining Account of his Arrival in an unknown Country in Terra Australis, after having suffer'd two Shipwrecks: Of the strange Manners and Customs of the People: Of his curious Conversations with the Priests, Judges, and with the KING himself, on the Sub
jects of Religion, Trade, and almost all the Arts and Sciences: Of his Passage from the Southern Countries to Goa, where he was imprison'd in the Inquisition: Of his being taken by Pirates in his Voyage from thence to Lisbon; and of his Ransom from Slavery, and Arrival at London: Besides many other most di
verting Incidents, which are very agreeably interspers'd in the Narrative.

Just Publish'd, The BOARDING SCHOOL; or, The SHAM CAPTAIN. An Opera. As it is perform'd at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane, by His Majesty's Servants: Written by Mr. COFFEE, Author of the Beggar's Wedding, and The Devil to Pay. With the Musick prefixt to each Song.
Also just Publish'd the last New Play, call'd, CAELIA, or, The Perjur'd LOVER, as it is Acted at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane, by His Majesty's Servants.
N. B. This Play is founded on a True Tragical Story in Common Life, and the Incidents very Natural and Moving.
And the Second Edition of The MOCK DOCTOR: Or, The DUMB LADY Cur'd, a Comedy done from Moliere, with additional SONGS and Alterations.

*†* Feb. 28, 1732. In a few Days will be Publish'd, The MISER. A Comedy, taken from Plautus and Moliere. By HENRY FIELDING, Esq. As it is now Acting at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane, by His Majesty's Servants.
div.trailer: Printed for John Watts at the Printing-Office in Wild-Court near Lincoln's-Inn Fields.
